metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: This section introduces the different data types available in Bash scripting.
content.html: This section introduces the different data types available in Bash scripting.

content.text: Strings are sequences of characters used to store text. They can be manipulated using various string operations such as concatenation and substring extraction.
content.html: Strings are sequences of characters used to store text. They can be manipulated using various string operations such as concatenation and substring extraction.

content.code:
# String example


greeting
=
"Hello, World!"


name
=
"Alice"


full_greeting
=
"
$greeting
,
$name
!"


echo

$full_greeting
content.code_html:
# String example
greeting="Hello, World!"
name="Alice"
full_greeting="$greeting, $name!"
echo $full_greeting

content.text: Numbers in Bash can be used for arithmetic operations. Bash supports integer arithmetic natively, such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.
content.html: Numbers in Bash can be used for arithmetic operations. Bash supports integer arithmetic natively, such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.

content.code:
# Number example


num1
=
5


num2
=
10


sum
=
$((
num1
+
num2
))


difference
=
$((
num2
-
num1
))


product
=
$((
num1
*
num2
))


quotient
=
$((
num2
/
num1
))


echo

"Sum:
$sum
, Difference:
$difference
, Product:
$product
, Quotient:
$quotient
"
content.code_html:
# Number example
num1=5
num2=10
sum=$((num1 + num2))
difference=$((num2 - num1))
product=$((num1 * num2))
quotient=$((num2 / num1))
echo "Sum: $sum, Difference: $difference, Product: $product, Quotient: $quotient"

content.text: Arrays are used to store multiple values in a single variable. Each element in an array is accessed using an index. You can iterate over arrays and modify elements.
content.html: Arrays are used to store multiple values in a single variable. Each element in an array is accessed using an index. You can iterate over arrays and modify elements.

content.code:
# Array example


fruits
=
(
"apple"

"banana"

"cherry"
)


for

fruit

in

"
${fruits
[
@
]
}
"
;

do


echo

$fruit


done
content.code_html:
# Array example
fruits=("apple" "banana" "cherry")
for fruit in "${fruits[@]}"; do
  echo $fruit
done

content.text: Associative arrays allow you to use named keys to access values. They are similar to dictionaries in other programming languages. You can add or remove keys and values.
content.html: Associative arrays allow you to use named keys to access values. They are similar to dictionaries in other programming languages. You can add or remove keys and values.

content.code:
# Associative array example


declare
-A colors
colors
[
apple
]
=
"red"

colors
[
banana
]
=
"yellow"

colors
[
grape
]
=
"purple"


unset
colors
[
banana
]


echo

${colors
[
apple
]
}

# red


echo

${colors
[
grape
]
}

# purple
content.code_html:
# Associative array example
declare -A colors
colors[apple]="red"
colors[banana]="yellow"
colors[grape]="purple"
unset colors[banana]
echo ${colors[apple]} # red
echo ${colors[grape]} # purple

content.text: Bash does not support floating-point arithmetic natively. For such operations, consider using external tools like bc or awk .
content.html: Bash does not support floating-point arithmetic natively. For such operations, consider using external tools like bc or awk.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
